pr_title: Sb bazel haskell cabal library rule

timeline.message: refactor: class renaming in preparation for making bazel pipelines more generic, in preparation for adding haskell rule support
feat(bazel): added Pipeline and associated classes
test: adapting tests to new bazel class structure
feat(bazel): Added haskell cabal library pipeline
style(help): Added doc for new bazel haskell_cabal_library functionality

timeline.bodyText: Did you consider creating gson/pojo model classes?
timeline.author: taikuukaits

replies.bodyText: I did... Bazel is very unstable (3 major versions in the last 8 months, and they include breaking changes even in minor versions), and I thought this might be more resilient to change. But I'm not actually sure of that... do you happen to know?
replies.author: stevebillings

replies.bodyText:
It probably depends on the changes, any idea what they typically change and will you need to support multiple models at the same time? I'd be hesitant to do the POJO if the changes were deeper than field renames - like if they were collections and the types stored in the collection changes.
If it is just field name changes, having muliple fields on the POJO some of which might be empty seems reasonable to me, and your code is just defensive against missing fields which it needs to be in the JsonElement case anyway.
I think
If pojo.myField != null then haskellName = pojo.myField else haskellName = pojo.otherField
seems better than
if json.containsField("myField") then haskellName = pojo.getFieldAsString("myField") else haskellName = pojo.getFieldAsString("otherField")
I would definitely understand the json element if the two models are dramatically different and cannot be mashed together.
replies.author: taikuukaits

replies.bodyText: changed it to a gson/pojo approach.
replies.author: stevebillings

timeline.author: JakeMathews

timeline.bodyText:
Why not use the GraphAssert class?
Also do we have to test that all the component pieces of ExternalId are set correctly? I think comparing the String result from ExternalId::createExternalId should be sufficient.
timeline.author: JakeMathews

timeline.bodyText: Can Gson not parse this Json?
timeline.author: JakeMathews

replies.bodyText: changed it to a gson/pojo approach.
replies.author: stevebillings

timeline.bodyText: I'd like to suggest more separation from parsing from transforming - you could have this Step use a Parser where the parser takes the string and returns say List of HaskellDependency and then the Step knows how to transform them into a dependency that is added to the graph, you are close as it is. I'd think extractHaskellCabalLibraryRule does all the json parsing and returns a well formed HaskellDependency and instead of returning a JsonObject that later work is done to, do all the json work up front and return a pojo. Then addDependencyToGraph doesn't take a JsonObject but takes in the HaskellDependency pojo. Then in your tests you can have a test that checks JsonObject -> HaskellDependency works and a test that List of HaskellDependency -> Graph. Would let you have smaller more isolated tests.
timeline.author: taikuukaits

timeline.message: refactor: addressing code review feedback; first, a few simple changes
refactor: split parser out from FinalStepJsonProtoHaskellCabalLibraries
test: added test for bazel haskell parser
refactor(bazel): haskell: first cut at pojo based parsing
refactor(bazel): haskell: error checking for unexpected query output
